Tsinghua University http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/SciValFunders/501100004147 http://sws.geonames.org/1814991/ Dr. Jun Ge is a professor at Department of Chemical Engineering Tsinghua University. He received his B.Sc. and Ph.D. from the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University in 2004 and 2009. From 2009 to 2012, He did his postdoc in the Department of Chemistry, Stanford University. Prof. Ge specializes in enzymatic catalysis, synthetic biology, nanobiotechnology and biomedicine. He has been carrying out scientific research projects from government and industry, including the Distinguished Young Scholars Fund from NSFC, the Excellent Young Scientists Fund from NSFC, the Program of National Key Research and Development Plan of China, and the Distinguished Young Scholars of Beijing National Science Foundation. Prof. Ge has published over 100 papers in journals such as Nature Nanotechnology, Nature Catalysis, Nature Communications, Science Advances, JACS etc. He was selected as the member of MIT Technology Review's World 35 Innovators Under 35 and was awarded as the young scholar of Yangzi River Scholarship and the Future Chemical Engineering Scholar of the Global Academy of Chinese Chemical Engineers. This work was supported by the Beijing Natural Science Foundation (L212019), the National Key R&D Program of China (2023YFA0913600), the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars of China IMAGE-HIGH-RES CHNJC 60274 S1872-2067(24)60274-3 10.1016/S1872-2067(24)60274-3 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 Synthesis of HMF and its oxidation derivatives. Fig. 2 Immobilization of enzymes, cells and chemical catalysts and the carriers. Fig. 3 The immobilization of enzymes in the synthesis of HMF. (A) SEM images of conventional cross-linked enzymes aggregates (CLEAs) and porous CLEAs. (B) The reusability of the immobilized biocatalysts, specifically CLEAs and porous CLEAs (pCLEAs) of Candida antarctica lipase B (CaLB). This process included hydration, isomerization and dehydration reactions. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [59]. Copyright 2021, Elsevier. (C) Cascade catalytic reactions of thermophilic glucose isomerase and solid acid catalysts in functionalized silica. This process included isomerization and dehydration reactions. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [64]. Copyright 2014, American Chemical Society. (D) Schematic representation of the cascaded enzymatic and chemical steps for IL pretreated cellulose into HMF. This process included hydration, isomerization and dehydration reactions. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [66]. Copyright 2017, Wiley. Fig. 4 The immobilization of enzymes in the synthesis of HMF oxidation derivatives. (A) An enzymatic nanoreactor exhibiting enhanced catalytic performance was developed by integrating CALB within the pores of a methylated β-cyclodextrin-derived silica matrix. (B) The catalytic recyclability of the biocatalysts, specifically RaMeβCD-SiO2@CAG@CALB@P4VP. This process included oxidative dehydrogenation and oxidation reactions. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [70]. Copyright 2021, Elsevier. (C) A schematic representation illustrated the immobilization process of Fe3O4-CotA-TJ102. (D) The time course for the biosynthesis of FFCA from the selective oxidation of HMF using free CotA-TJ102 under optimal conditions. This process included oxidative dehydrogenation and oxidation reactions. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [72]. Copyright 2019, Elsevier. (E) Images depicting SEM and confocal microscopy for GO0.05@NECu(II)8 were included. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [74]. Copyright 2022, Elsevier. (F) The conversion of HMF by GO&Hem@Cu(II) in aqueous conditions was reported. This process was oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [75]. Copyright 2023, Elsevier. Fig. 5 The immobilization of cells in the synthesis of HMF and its oxidation derivatives. (A) The SEM imaged depict various aspects of chitosan beads. (B) The influence of initial pH on the degradation of HMF and furfural from a simulated hydrolysate in a free cells culture of Bordetella sp. Continuous lines represent HMF and discontinuous lines represent furfural. This process included hydration, isomerization and dehydration reactions. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [81]. Copyright 2019, Elsevier. (C) HMF was synthesized from pineapple peel utilizing Cr(III) chloride (CrCl3) at a temperature of 100 °C. (D) A scale-up process for the production of FDCA via APLS-1. This process included oxidative dehydrogenation and oxidation reactions. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [83]. Copyright 2023, Elsevier. Review Synthesis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and its oxidation derivatives by immobilized catalysts: An efficient green sustainable technology Yao Chen a Jun Ge a b c * a Key Lab of Industrial Biocatalysis, Ministry of Education, Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Key Lab of Industrial Biocatalysis Ministry of Education Department of Chemical Engineering Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Key Lab of Industrial Biocatalysis, Ministry of Education, Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China b State Key Laboratory of Green Biomanufacturing, Beijing 100084, China State Key Laboratory of Green Biomanufacturing Beijing 100084 China State Key Laboratory of Green Biomanufacturing, Beijing 100084, China c Center for Synthetic and Systems Biology, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Center for Synthetic and Systems Biology Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Center for Synthetic and Systems Biology, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China * Corresponding author. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and its oxidation derivatives have emerged as a bridge between biomass resources and the future energy industry. These renewable biomass resources can be transformed into a variety of value-added chemicals, thereby addressing the challenges posed by diminishing fossil fuel reserves and environmental concerns. The immobilization of catalysts represents an innovative method for the sustainable and efficient synthesis of HMF and its oxidation derivatives. This method not only enhances the yield and selectivity of the products but also allows for the optimization of the catalytic performance of immobilized catalysts through the strategic design of their supports. In this review, we provide an overview of the recent advancements in the technology of immobilized catalyst and its application in the synthesis of HMF and its oxidation derivatives, with a particular focus on the preparation and catalytic characteristics of these immobilized catalysts. Furthermore, we discuss potential future directions for the development of immobilized catalysts, including the preparation of high-performance immobilized catalysts, the exploration of their growth and catalytic mechanisms, and the economic implications of raw material utilization. This area of research presents both significant promise and considerable challenges. Graphical Abstract The immobilization of catalysts and carriers provides a new strategy for the efficient green sustainable synthesis of high-value chemicals HMF and its oxidized derivatives. Keywords 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Oxidized derivatives Immobilization Immobilized catalyst Catalytic property 1 Introduction The escalating demand for energy, coupled with the depletion of fossil fuel resources and the degradation of the ecological environment, has emerged as a central concern in the context of global green development. The “2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development” seeks to mitigate carbon dioxide emissions through the adoption of clean and renewable technologies, the design of energy-efficient chemical processes that minimize material and energy inputs, and the promotion of recycling, reuse, and the valorization of waste raw materials [1–5]. The primary alternative carbon sources identified are carbon dioxide itself and biomass processes that utilize carbon dioxide. Currently, biomass resources account for only 15% of energy and 10% of material inputs [6], while the capture and utilization of carbon dioxide remains largely in the exploratory phase. Consequently, biomass resources have emerged as the most promising raw materials within the green chemical industry. Among various biomass resources, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is gaining prominence and has been identified as one of the most significant bio-based chemicals capable of being transformed into a range of value-added products. HMF is also regarded as a crucial intermediary between biomass resources and fossil fuel-based industries [7,8]. The unique structural characteristics of HMF, including the redox properties of its hydroxyl and aldehyde functional groups, as well as its furan aromatic ring, enable the derivation of additional value-added materials, thereby potentially influencing the development of a burgeoning bio-based economy [9]. The synthesis of HMF typically involves the hydrolysis of polysaccharides, such as cellulose, to yield glucose. Subsequently, glucose undergoes isomerization to produce fructose, and fructose can also be directly extracted from biomass such as Jerusalem artichoke, which is then subjected to dehydration to generate HMF. The biomass products generated through the oxidation reactions of HMF's functional groups primarily encompass 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 2-formyl-5-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), adipic acid and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [10]. The most prevalent and representative oxidation derivatives include DFF, HMFCA, FFCA and FDCA, which are the primary focus of this review. (Fig. 1 ) HMF has great potential to become one of the most important C6 platform chemicals in biorefinery [11]. Nonetheless, the current pricing of raw materials and the atomic efficiency of industrial processes for HMF and its oxidative derivatives remain suboptimal, resulting in elevated production costs that hinder its competitiveness in the industrial sector [12,13]. The substantial economic potential of this market has motivated numerous researchers and commercial enterprises to explore innovative pathways for the synthesis of HMF and its oxidative derivatives. Statistical projections indicate that the market value of FDCA alone is expected to reach approximately 770 million euros by 2025, with a compound annual growth rate of around 11% [1,14]. In 2014, a Swiss company AVA Biochemical established the first small-scale plant capable of producing 300 tons of HMF annually. Recently, the company has announced plans to scale up production to between 5000 and 10000 tons per year. Additionally, Avantium Holding BV intends to construct a flagship plant in Geleen with a capacity of 5,000 tons of FDCA. Other chemical companies are also advancing proprietary catalytic technologies aimed at the production of HMF and its oxidative derivatives. For example, in 2019, Novamont company declared an investment of 10 million euros aimed at the establishment of a demonstration facility in Italy, which was focused on the advancement of FDCA synthesis through the catalytic oxidation of HMF [1,15]. For an extended period, the conventional chemical catalytic methods have predominated in the synthesis of HMF and its derivatives [16–20]. This reaction typically occurs within a temperature range of 100–150 °C, with a reaction duration of 1 to 10 h, utilizing molecular oxygen as the oxidizing agent. Despite numerous significant advancements and breakthroughs in this field, several challenges remain. Firstly, traditional chemical catalytic methods often employ costly metal catalysts, which diminishes their economic viability. Furthermore, a prevalent issue associated with certain metals is the generation of by-products in aqueous environments, attributable to side reactions such as polymerization, ring opening, hydrolysis, and nucleophilic addition. The presence of undesirable secondary reactions and the resultant low-value byproducts significantly constrain the selectivity of the reaction. However, conventional chemical catalytic methods can achieve favorable outcomes under extreme reaction conditions, including elevated temperatures, high pressures, and the use of corrosive reactants. Furthermore, many traditional catalytic processes necessitate the use of organic solvents as reaction media, which, from a green chemistry standpoint, are not environmentally sustainable. In contrast to chemical catalytic methods, the synthesis of HMF under mild conditions frequently employs glucose isomerase and fructose dehydratase. Additionally, alcohol dehydrogenase and aldehyde oxidase are utilized to catalyze the oxidation of HMF, thereby enhancing the selectivity of the oxidation derivatives. Nevertheless, enzymes and cells catalysis typically necessitate particular temperature and pH conditions, and it is difficult to achieve reuse. In light of the aforementioned challenges, there is a pressing need to advance the catalytic pathway for upgrading immobilized catalysts, which offer benefits such as high selectivity, mild operational conditions, cost-effectiveness, and environmental sustainability [21–25]. This method could be actively pursued as a viable alternative to current technologies. Biocatalysts typically encompass enzymes and cells [26–33], whereas chemical catalysts are often represented by small molecules, including metals and ions [34–40]. Nonetheless, these catalysts frequently encounter issues such as difficulties in product separation, low catalytic efficiency, susceptibility to deactivation, and limited reusability. In this regard, the immobilization technology for enzymes, cells, or chemical catalysts emerges as a significant strategy for the future conversion of biomass resources. A critical component of this technology is the use of immobilization carriers, which primarily consist of metal-organic frameworks, polymers, and porous inorganic structures, etc. The interactions between carriers and catalysts encompass various binding modes, including adsorption, covalent bonding, in-situ embedding, and cross-linking. These entities are interconnected through covalent bonds, hydrogen bonds, dipole interactions, as well as electrostatic and hydrophobic interaction. The application of immobilization technology is likely to diminish catalytic activity to a certain degree. This reduction is primarily attributed to the carriers may interact with the surface of the biocatalysts and chemical catalysts, potentially altering the three-dimensional conformation of the biocatalysts and the electronic state of the chemical catalysts, which in turn can influence catalytic performance. Furthermore, immobilized biocatalysts and chemical catalysts may exhibit a propensity to aggregate or agglomerate, leading to a decrease in surface area and, consequently, a decline in catalytic efficiency. Notably, the selection of an appropriate carriers for immobilization is also a critical consideration, these catalysts often demonstrate a catalytic efficiency that exceeds the sum of their individual contributions, particularly when protected by carriers and usually enhances their stability (temperature stability and pH stability) and reusability. So, this phenomenon may offer a promising method for the synthesis of desired target products (Fig. 2 ). This review focuses on HMF and its common oxidative derivatives, with a comprehensive discussion on the application of immobilization technology. Specifically, the synthesis methods, structural properties, product selectivity, and catalytic efficiency of these immobilized catalysts are emphasized. Furthermore, we explore potential future directions for the development of immobilized catalysts, which encompass the fabrication of high-performance immobilized catalysts, the growth and catalytic mechanisms associated with these catalysts, and the economic implications of raw material utilization in catalytic field. 2 Immobilization of biocatalysts Fluctuations in temperature and pH can lead to rapid inactivation of enzymes and cells, and these biocatalysts often exhibit limited reusability and pose challenges in separation from solution. In recent years, advancements in enzymes and cells immobilization technology have garnered significant attention. This method offers enhanced protective measures for these biocatalysts, thereby diminishing their susceptibility to environmental fluctuations, enhancing their reusability, and preserving their catalytic efficacy. In the field of enzymes immobilization research, a variety of carriers have been developed, including hydrogel, carbon-based materials, silicon-based materials, covalent organic frameworks (COFs), and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [42–46]. The effective utilization of these carriers can be attributed to their enhanced loading efficiency, uniform distribution, diverse skeletal compositions, abundant organic ligands, and favorable biocompatibility. Recently, there has been a gradual advancement in the development of immobilized catalysts that incorporate metal single atom-anchored enzymes [41]. However, current methods of enzymes immobilization still exhibit several limitations, including enzymes leakage, conformational alterations, enzymes deactivation, and an unclear structure-activity relationship [47–49]. Nonetheless, it is important to recognize that these innovative concepts provide a robust foundation for future advancements in efficient industrial catalysis, and further development and expansion of these systems hold significant potential for recognition and application within the industry. Cells that contain a diverse array of enzymes and cofactors are capable of executing multi-enzymes cascade reactions without the necessity for enzymes purification. However, the environmental tolerance of free cells is relatively low. The repeated application of whole-cells catalysts in high-pressure industrial settings can result in cells lysis, thereby impeding the further utilization of these whole cells [50–54]. In response to this challenge, the introduction of artificial spores in 2013 marked the inception of a hybrid system for cells immobilization [55–58]. Drawing inspiration from artificial spores, various innovative composite carriers have been developed for the immobilization of cells. These immobilized cells exhibit enhanced durability, selective permeability, degradability, and functionalization. Concurrently, the emergence of click chemistry has facilitated the covalent immobilization of living cells under mild reaction conditions. 2.1 Immobilization of enzymes In recent years, the immobilization of enzymes has gained prominence. Regarding enzymes immobilization for HMF synthesis, the utilization of flexible organic carriers facilitates the formation of a network structure that ensures a uniform distribution and cross-linking of the enzymes. Saikia et al. [59] indicated that three-phase partitioning (TPP) enhances the preparation of porous cross-linked aggregates of Candida antarctica lipase B (CALB) for HMF synthesis (Figs. 3 (A) and (B) ). It was established that the immobilized CALB demonstrates stable functionality within a pH range of 6.0 to 9.0 and at temperatures between 40 and 60 °C, exhibiting a catalytic efficiency that was 2.2 times greater than that of the free enzymes. However, only 44% of the immobilized enzyme activity remained after 8 cycles, which may be due to the loss of the enzyme caused by the surface immobilization and continuous washing of the biocatalyst. In a notable advancement, an innovative organic liquid membrane dynamic reactor incorporating immobilized glucose isomerase and acid resin was synthesized, achieving a glucose conversion rate of 70%, with a 20% HMF yield [61]. Similarly, aminated beads functionalized with glutaraldehyde were utilized for the immobilization of ATAs, which included the incorporation of a specialized selective binding site. In the catalytic reaction involving HMF with alanine serving as a co-substrate, all immobilized ATAs demonstrated effective reusability over five cycles, achieving HMF conversion rate of 41% over a period of 12 d [62]. Additionally, Alipour et al. [60] successfully immobilized glucose isomerase for the isomerization process, resulting in the dehydration of ketose to HMF with a reaction yield exceeding 80% under mild conditions. Building upon this foundation, Grande et al. [63] introduced the concept of chemical enzymes capable of converting glucose into HMF in seawater. The integration of these enzymes with bio-based acids presents a promising avenue for biorefinery applications following further optimization of the concept. The significant advantage of the flexible organic carriers is that it can create an optimal microenvironment for the enzymes. It facilitates the optimization of the enzymes’ catalytic conditions through pH adjustment and allows for modifications in porosity and hydrophilicity to meet varying reaction requirements. This adaptability contributes to the maintenance of the enzymes’ structural stability and enhances its catalytic efficiency. Silicon carriers play a significant role in biocatalysts. Recently, Huang et al. [64] innovatively combined a thermophilic glucose isomerase and a solid acid catalyst with –NH2-functionalized mesoporous silica and cascaded –SO3H-functionalized silica for direct one-pot glucose to HMF conversion in a single-phase solvent system consisting of tetrahydrofuran (THF) and H2O (4:1 v/v) and at 90 °C for 24 h with 30% HMF yield. Nevertheless, the enzyme could not be recycled because its short half-life (t 1/2 = 15.8 min) in the organic solvent and the efficiency of the tandem system is greatly hindered by the large discrepancy in rates for the two catalysts. Studies to further improve the enzyme stability and the efficiency of fructose dehydration are in progress (Fig. 3(C)). Additionally, Lee et al. [65] showed the co-immobilization of cellulase and isomerase on mesoporous silica nanoparticles that possess various acidic functional groups, including H2PO3, COOH, and SO3H. This method yielded an optimal HMF production of 45.6%. However, the yield of HMF was reduced by 7% after 5 cycles. This loss is possibly due to surface deactivation of MSNs and inaccessible HSO3 groups with each cycle. Concurrently, Zhang et al. [66] developed an innovative pathway for the cascade enzymes-catalyzed deconstruction of cellulose into HMF. This method involved the grafting of zirconia onto SBA-15 to create an encapsulated nano catalyst, with a HMF yield of 43.6% (Fig. 3(D)). The relatively low conversion rate of HMF in silicon carriers immobilized enzymes may be attributed to the increased distance between active sites of enzymes and substrates. This spatial separation diminishes the frequency of interactions between the enzymes and its substrate. Furthermore, the hydrophobic characteristics of the silicon carrier may alter the three-dimensional conformation of enzymes, thereby impacting its catalytic activity and potentially intensifying its inhibitory effects on the substrate. Though some promising results have been achieved in silicon carriers immobilized enzymes, the research of the effect of carrier hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity on enzyme activity is relatively scarce and needs more attention in future researches. In a similar vein, carbon nanotubes were extensively utilized as carriers for biological enzymes, attributing to their stable carbon skeleton structure, which was similarities with silicon carrier. The enzymes were primarily adsorbed and linked through functionalization processes. Wang et al. [67] grafted heparin onto multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) that were coated with polydopamine (PDA) and polyethyleneimine (PEI). This modification facilitated hydrogen bond interactions between the monosaccharide fructose and the enzymes, resulting in a HMF yield of 46.2%. Currently, the synthesis of HMF via immobilized enzymes requires further optimization. Consequently, exploring the enhancement of HMF yield through the incorporation of various cofactors represented a significant avenue of research. Lin et al. [68] demonstrated that the acid resistance of co-immobilized glucose oxidase and catalase could be improved by the introduction of ε-polylysine. Additionally, the chelation of gluconic acid with Ca2+ facilitates the release of sufficient protons, resulting in an HMF yield of 85% when subjected to microwave stimulation at 150 °C for 10 minutes. Even though not much work is done in microwave-assisted HMF synthesis, but optimal power, reaction time and enzymes loading under acoustic cavitation must be selected to give effective intensification in HMF synthesis. Furthermore, there had an innovative method involving the synthesis of HMF through the addition of dioxane and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) in aprotic polar solvents, utilizing immobilized glucose isomerase and lipase. Although this method owned only 15% yield, it nonetheless confirmed the influence of these cofactors on the performance of immobilized enzymes [69]. Dioxane and DMSO systems are generally effective in minimizing the incidence of side reactions and enhancing the selectivity of HMF synthesis. However, these systems are associated with relatively high costs, and the processes involved in the recovery and reuse of solvents may be more complex, thereby impacting the overall economic viability. In the investigation of immobilized enzymes catalysis for the production of HMF oxidation derivatives, Decarpigny et al. [70] employed methylated β-cyclodextrin as a template to synthesize silica particles with tunable pore sizes via the sol-gel process in an alkaline environment. They subsequently covalently bonded lipase to the surface of these silica particles and oxidized DFF to yield FDCA. After conducting the reaction at 40 °C for 7 h, the catalytic activity was observed to be twice that of the free enzymes, with over 90% of the activity retained after 5 cycles. This can be related to the loss of the smallest particles along successive rinsing steps that caused a decrease in the amount of enzyme remaining in the reaction mixture (Fig. 4(A) and (B) . Building upon this method, a general method for the immobilization of lipases within silicon-enhanced cyclodextrin-derived supramolecular hydrogels was formulated. This innovative structure featured a more accessible exchange channel and a versatile interface that was both hydrophilic and hydrophobic. As a result, it has achieved a fourfold increase in the DFF conversion rate, yielding 100% FDCA within 7 h. Given that the furanic compounds formed during this reaction (FFCA and FDCA) bear carboxylic acid moieties in their cycle, they are likely to lower the pH in the vicinity of the enzyme, thereby creating an acidic microenvironment that can inhibit the lipase activity [71]. The enhancement of catalytic activity observed in the synthesis of FDCA from DFF, facilitated by lipase immobilized on silicon carriers, can be attributed to the researchers’ investigation of the hydrophilic and hydrophobic properties of the silicon carriers’ surface. This examination likely contributed to the stabilization of the enzyme's structure. Future research focusing on the immobilization of enzymes for FDCA synthesis should consider the structure-activity relationship of enzymes, as enzyme activity is intricately linked to their conformational states. Lipase can be effectively immobilized on macroporous resin, which exhibited favorable thermal stability and tolerance to organic solvents. Following 10 cycles of use, the conversion rate achieved was 52.6%. Moreover, resin properties such as porosity, bulk density, and mechanical stability can affect the operational performance and recycling efficiency of the immobilized enzyme [78]. Additionally, Daniel et al. [73] integrated immobilized enzymes with continuous packed bed microbial reactors, utilizing macroporous resin carrier for catalytic reactions. This method resulted in a 20% increase in yield and a 1000-fold enhancement in specific yield compared to traditional membrane bioreactors. This innovative bioreactor design offered valuable insights for applications within the biomass energy sector. Furthermore, for the first time, TEMPO and magnetic laccase were employed to create a novel immobilized catalyst. After a reaction period of 96 h, complete conversion of HMF was achieved, yielding a quantitative yield of 90.2% for FDCA. Notably, the catalyst retained 84.8% of its original activity after being reused 6 times, due to laccase inactivation upon reuse [79]. Research had demonstrated that laccase derived from Bacillus subtilis possesses the capability to convert HMF into FFCA without further oxidation to FDCA. Zhang et al. [72] immobilized this enzyme onto magnetic nanoparticles Fe3O4, resulting in a significant enhancement of FFCA yield from 19.3% to 98.55%, while the conversion rate of HMF increased from 23.5% to nearly 100%. Furthermore, after 10 cycles of use, the yield of FFCA remained at 83.28%, with a selectivity of 98.6% (Figs. 4 (C) and (D)). Promising outcomes were achieved through the immobilization of the enzymes on MOF carriers and metal oxide carriers. The active site of the enzymes and the carriers exhibited distinct solid acid-base properties, which significantly influenced the activation of HMF and the selectivity of the resulting products. By modulating the doping ratios of various catalyst components, it is possible to tailor the acidity and alkalinity of the catalyst, thereby enhancing its catalytic performance. In the context of enzymes-metal immobilization catalysts, Chen et al. [74] co-immobilized galactose oxidase (GO) with Cu(II) and Zr(IV) to create inorganic hybrid nanoflowers, which facilitated the continuous activation of GO through the in-situ generation of free radicals and oxygen. Under these conditions, the conversion rate of HMF reached 98.1% within 10 h, representing a 4.5-fold increase compared to the performance of the free enzymes (Fig. 4(E)). Subsequently, Cu(II) was co-immobilized with GO and Hematin to create a novel hybrid nanoflower capable of decomposing the by-product H2O2 to generate free radicals. This method achieved a remarkable 99.5% conversion of HMF within 3 hours, which was 5.8 times more effective than the free enzymes (Fig. 4(F)) [75]. Building on this foundation, other researchers have successfully immobilized GO, CAT, and SOD alongside Cu(II) to produce recyclable O2, achieving a conversion rate of 97% within 2 h [76]. In the context of reductive amination of HMF using alanine as a co-substrate, the immobilized configuration yielded an impressive 87% conversion, further underscoring the significant role of the amine functional construction module in the chemical industry [77]. Beginning with the enzyme itself, it is noteworthy to develop a carrier that can simultaneously decompose by-products and activate the enzyme's active site, thereby enhancing the conversion rate of HMF. The efficient preparation of an optimal carrier tailored to the specific characteristics of the enzyme remains a challenge that warrants further investigation. Detailed information of the reaction of immobilization of enzymes are shown in Table 1 . 2.2 Immobilization of cells In the field of cells immobilization, researchers have successfully immobilized crude cells of Streptomyces coelicolor exhibiting glucose isomerase (GI) activity. These immobilized cells facilitated the conversion of glucose to HMF through a sequential chemical enzyme conversion process under sonochemical activation conditions, achieving a yield of 74% [80]. The immobilization technique significantly reduced both the reaction time and temperature in comparison to free cells, while also increasing the substrate processing capacity by a factor of 50. Additionally, chitosan was employed as a biocompatible carrier to immobilize Bordetella BTIITR for the degradation of lignin. This method demonstrated a broader operational range in terms of pH, temperature, and inhibitor concentration compared to free cells (Figs. 5 (A) and (B) ) [81]. Additionally, PVA1799-boric acid and sodium alginate-Ca2+ were utilized for the immobilization of the BF60 strain in the production of FDCA. It was determined that sodium alginate-Ca2+ exhibited more favorable properties, with Ca(H2PO4)2 serving as the crosslinking agent. Under optimized conditions, this method yielded a higher production of FDCA. The newly established methodology offers a theoretical framework for the cost-effective production of FDCA [82]. As shown in Fig. 5(C) and (D), to enhance production capabilities, pineapple peel was pioneered utilized as a raw material for the development of a cascade involving Aspergillus flavus APLS-1 and CrCl3 within a 2.5 L fermenter for the synthesis of FDCA. The sharply drop in FDCA yield after 2 days was mainly due to the catalyst blocking the bioreactor circuit, and the leakage of the medium increases the risk of pollution. At the same time, the use of calcium alginate beads led to slow medium transfer [83]. Despite the current low yield, this innovative and cost-effective method held potential for further optimization, particularly in the context of biological immobilization processes. Currently, there is a lack of reported applications of immobilized cells in the production of DFF, HMFCA and FFCA, and there are few studies on the synthesis of HMF and FDCA. The main reason is that the environment required for the synthesis of these substances, such as pH, has a great damage to the activity of cells. At the same time, the generated target products and by-products have certain cytotoxicity, and the carrier selection with good biocompatibility also further limits the rapid development of cell immobilization. Therefore, the use of immobilized cell technology has certain technical challenges in the synthesis of HMF and its oxidative derivatives. First of all, it is necessary to further clarify the interaction mechanism between the biotransformation pathway and intracellular enzymes, so as to provide a basis for cell immobilization. Secondly, cells can be rapidly screened by AI and genetic engineering to obtain cells with better environmental tolerance and catalytic performance. At the same time, further research should be carried out on cell immobilization carriers and immobilization methods, and new carriers with good biocompatibility and mass transfer characteristics should be developed, supplemented by in-situ immobilization and other means to jointly improve the catalytic performance and reusability of cells. Detailed information of the reaction of immobilization of cells are shown in Table 2 . 3 Immobilization of chemical catalysts The initial concept of immobilizing chemical catalysts can be traced back to the metal nanoparticles (NPs) catalyst introduced in the 1970s. This method garnered significant interest from both industrial and fundamental research sectors, owing to the distinctive magnetic, optical, and catalytic properties exhibited by these nanoparticles [84]. The benefits associated with NPs necessitate a more nuanced regulation of various parameters, including dispersibility, stability, and particularly, particle size. Traditional methods for synthesizing NPs, such as impregnation, co-precipitation, and deposition precipitation, often resulted in challenges such as suboptimal particle size distribution, functional interference among metals, and inadequate affinity. Furthermore, the high surface energy of small NPs complicated the assembly of metals with differing physical and chemical characteristics, frequently leading to uneven alloying and significant aggregation [85–87]. Additionally, when focusing primarily on gold as a model for research before extending to other metals, several issues persisted, including the requirement for stringent conditions, a lack of universally applicable methods, and limited dispersion due to the constraints imposed by Ostwald ripening [90]. To enhance the catalytic efficacy of chemical catalysts, numerous researchers sought to mitigate the detrimental effects associated with these systems. One of the methods involved the immobilization of NPs within specialized porous materials, which facilitated their stabilization through robust interactions and spatial confinement effects, thereby preventing aggregation during both synthesis and catalytic processes [88,89]. The immobilization of active transition metal complexes onto organic polymers, inorganic oxides, and various other substrates for the purpose of catalyst preparation has garnered significant interest. The supporting materials utilized in this process encompass both flexible and rigid carriers [91–94]. Initially, traditional zeolites served as rigid carriers; however, significant advancements were made in the synthesis of non-aluminum silicate-based crystalline porous materials. Furthermore, silicon-based immobilized clusters emerged as effective catalyst carriers. A novel category of porous carrier MOFs has recently been introduced. Comparable to mesoporous silica and zeolites, these carriers serve as effective stabilizers and homogenizers, thereby inhibiting the growth and/or aggregation of metal NPs. Nonetheless, the thermal stability of MOFs poses constraints on their potential applications. Flexible supports, primarily composed of polymers, offering a diverse range of compositions, synthetic adaptability, and adjustable physical properties, enabling them to cross-link and self-assemble with chemical catalysts to create new catalytic systems. 3.1 Immobilized of chemical catalysts for HMF synthesis In recent years, the immobilization technology of chemical catalysts has been increasingly utilized in the synthesis of HMF to enhance the low efficiency associated with these catalysts. In the report on the synthesis of HMF, the catalytic properties of iron were used as the core element of immobilized catalyst. Matharu et al. [95] focused on HMF synthesis, employed iron-N-heterocyclic carbon complexes (Fe-NHCs) as the core. These complexes were immobilized on mesoporous expanded starch and Starbon350, resulting in the development of heterogeneous catalysts (Fig. 6(A) ). These catalysts were subsequently applied in the conversion of fructose to synthesize HMF. In comparative analyses, it was observed that the Fe-NHC-HACS exhibited superior catalytic performance, achieving a fructose conversion rate of 87% and a high selectivity for HMF at 99%. Additionally, the ferromagnetic properties of the catalyst confer advantages in terms of recyclability. Following the amino modification of the Fe3O4 surface [96], Cr3(CH3COO)7(OH)2 was immobilized to create a magnetic chromium composite catalyst. Upon repeated utilization in an acidic specific ionic liquid (TSIL) for 6 cycles, the conversion of glucose to HMF was achieved without a significant decline in catalytic activity. However, the yield of HMF was suboptimal, recorded at only 57%, which might be caused by the mass loss of the catalyst during the washing and transferring progress. To address this limitation, certain researchers synthesized magnetic graphene oxide and subsequently immobilized propanesulfonic acid groups [97], resulting in an HMF yield of 87% when reacted in DMSO at 120 °C for 60 min. As a non-noble metal material, iron can be used as both a catalyst and a carrier, its efficacy in the synthesis of HMF is notable, and its recyclability, coupled with cost-effectiveness enhances its competitiveness in the realm of chemical catalytic synthesis of HMF. Nonetheless, the tendency of Fe3O4 to aggregate poses a challenge, leading to a reduction in catalytic activity. To address this issue, the incorporation of dispersants may be a viable solution. Mesoporous silica carriers increasingly were utilized for the immobilization of chemical catalysts, following significant interest in this area during the 1980s. The most notable and established carriers include SBA-15, SBA-16, and MCM-41. The surface of SBA-15 was modified through the grafting of metal chlorides, resulting in the formation of a heterogeneous catalyst, CrCl2-Im-SBA-15 [98,99]. However, this catalyst exhibited low selectivity and necessitates the use of a H2O:DMSO mixture as both the reaction medium and extraction layer to enhance the yield of HMF. Similarly, SBA-16 [100,101] was modified with propylsulfonic acid for the first time and utilized in the production of HMF. The resulting material, designated as SO3H@SBA-16, was synthesized by immobilizing mercaptopropyl onto SBA-16, followed by oxidation with hydrogen peroxide to introduce sulfonic acid groups. This catalyst demonstrated a yield of 91% for HMF and exhibited recyclability in the conversion of fructose to HMF. Meanwhile, the amount of acid groups in SBA-16/IL/acid after 5 cycles was slightly reduced from 1.47 to 1.26 mmol/g, which affected the enzyme activity. Subsequently, the research team anchored a sulfonated imidazolium ionic liquid onto the carrier via a click reaction, achieving a yield of 98% for HMF and allowing for 5 cycles of reuse. However, a notable limitation of these catalysts is their requirement for high-temperature reactions in DMSO at temperatures exceeding 110–120 °C. Additionally, mesoporous silica and halloysite had been explored as supports for the immobilization of heteropoly acids. Silicotungstic acid has been identified as an effective heterogeneous acid catalyst, with its immobilization on halloysite yielding an HMF production of 99.5% [102]. When silicotungstic acid is immobilized on mesoporous silica, it can be effectively surrounded by an aqueous fructose solution, which mitigates the deposition of humic substances on the catalyst's surface and enhances the selectivity for HMF [103]. Furthermore, bis-acid functionalized ionic liquids had been immobilized on silica to create ILs@SiO2, facilitating the preparation of HMF in an ethanol solution for the first time. The conversion rates for fructose, glucose, xylose, sucrose, and cellobiose were found to be 99%, 96%, 94%, 76%, and 99%, respectively [104]. Utilizing the same immobilization strategy, fructose conversion reached 99.9% in DMSO at 130 °C. However, the selectivity of this immobilized catalyst was somewhat inferior, yielding only 63% HMF [105]. Additionally, Dou et al. [106,107] had employed mesoporous silica to immobilize perfluorosulfonic acid (PFSA) resin, achieving an HMF yield of 85% in DMSO at 90 °C, with the catalyst being regenerated through a straightforward ion exchange method. In such a case, the minor activity loss might be due to the small amounts of organic byproducts remained within the pores of catalyst, which probably hampers the transportation effect of mesoporous silica. An alternative silicon-based structure, distinct from mesoporous silica, was represented by silicone hollow spheres as shown in Fig. 6(B). Utilizing this carrier for the immobilization of ILs allows for an increased loading capacity and adequate confinement space. The reaction was conducted in DMSO at a temperature of 100 °C for a duration of 2 h, resulting in a yield of 93.7%, which demonstrated no significant loss of catalytic activity after 6 cycles [108]. Cr(III) Schiff base complex and acidic IL were immobilized on MCM-41 with hexagonal ordered mesoporous structure. With glucose as the substrate, the optimal HMF yield reached 43.5% after treatment with DMSO at 140 °C for 4 h. The little activity loss may be caused by two reasons, firstly, the leaching of active components from the silica support surface in vigorous operating conditions, and secondly, the polymer produced in the reaction may be absorbed on the silica, thus poisoning the catalytic activity of the catalyst (Figs. 6 (C) and (D)) [109–111]. Ceramic powder is also a kind of silicon-based carrier. Using this carrier to immobilized Sn4+ ions and introduced HCl could obtain a yield of 63.9%. In general, the inevitable loss of small Sn-CP particles in the 5 cycles led to the increase of the overall size of Sn-CP, which in turn reduced the specific surface area of the particles and led to the decrease of catalyst activity [112]. The chemical inertness and thermal stability of silica carriers enhance its applicability, while its capacity for modification broadens the range of supported catalysts. Nonetheless, in certain specific environments, the affinity of the surface modifier for the catalyst may diminish, resulting in catalyst leaching and a subsequent decline in overall catalytic activity. Currently, this heterogeneous catalyst demonstrates satisfactory recyclability in laboratory settings. However, the associated recovery costs in practical industrial applications warrant careful consideration. Drawing inspiration from silica materials, a variety of oxide carriers have been developed. The integration of high silica loading with the magnetic characteristics of Fe3O4 facilitated the immobilization of ionic liquids (ILs) utilizing functionalized and magneto-optical dual-sensitizers through surface-initiated reversible addition-fragmentation chain transfer polymerization. This process resulted in the conversion of glucose to 86.7% HMF (Fig. 6(G)) [113]. The silica-coated magnetic nanoparticle in question can undergo functional modification, specifically through the immobilization of a sulfonic acid group via triazine dendrimer modification. This approach presents a novel strategy for the synthesis of HMF without the necessity for additional reaction solvent conditions [114]. Additionally, Zhang et al. [115] had incorporated TiO2, analogous to SiO2, to co-encapsulate Fe3O4 for the immobilization of phosphotungstic acid, thereby facilitating the catalytic conversion of inulin. Although this method yielded only 54% HMF, it represents a promising endeavor that enhances the potential for substrate diversity. UiO-66 was subjected to sulfonation and subsequently immobilized with polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP)-modified kaolin nanotubes. By adjusting the acidic functional sites of MOFs, the catalyst achieved a HMF yield of 92.4% (Figs. 6 (E) and (F)) [116]. Zhang et al. [117] had incorporated g-C3N4 with UiO-66 catalysts, achieving a HMF yield of 54.9% in a DMSO system. The slight loss of catalyst activity was mainly caused by generated byproducts preventing new reactant molecules from contacting the active sites on the catalyst surface (Figs. 7(A)–(C)). Utilizing Pluronic P123 as a structure-directing agent (SDA), phosphotungstic acid was successfully immobilized on SnO2 mesoporous material through a hydrothermal method. Under hydrothermal conditions within a water/toluene two-phase solvent system, fructose was dehydrated to yield HMF with an impressive yield of 95%. The decrease in yield might be due to the leaching of PTA from the MSnPTA catalyst (Fig. 7(D) ) [118]. The application of metal-immobilized modified activated carbon and metal-immobilized cellulose composites resulted in a HMF yield of 54.76%. While this approach presented a novel pathway, further enhancements are necessary to achieve greater efficiency. The decrease in the magnitude of product yield was due to the blockage of active sites of catalysts as a result of agglomeration of insoluble impurities and unreacted substrate over the surface of catalyst and in the bulk of particles. This agglomerating reduced the pore size and porosity of the catalysts, hence providing less surface area for the effective interaction of substrate with the catalysts hence declines the product yield [119]. The surface of carbon nanotubes was functionalized via a click reaction, leading to the immobilization of sulfonic acid groups. This catalyst demonstrated commendable catalytic activity and high recovery rates (Fig. 7(E)) [120]. Immobilized metal oxides are demonstrated having significant catalytic activity. However, optimal catalytic performance typically necessitates elevated temperatures. In practical applications, the selection of an appropriate metal oxide and suitable carriers, and the optimization of reaction conditions are critical factors for achieving efficient HMF synthesis. Polymer-based flexible carriers designed for the immobilization of chemical catalysts exhibit enhanced fluidity. However, they tend to provide relatively inadequate protection for the catalyst. A heterogeneous catalyst supported by polystyrene, which is functionalized with sulfonic acid, facilitates the hydrolysis of fructose to produce HMF [121]. Additionally, ILs had been immobilized using bifunctional lignosulfonates to catalyze the conversion of cellulose, glucose, and mannose, yielding HMF outputs of 46.3%, 60.4%, and 68.8%, respectively, although there was a slight loss of active metal ions [122,123]. Regenerated cellulose has also been employed as a carrier for the immobilization of niobic acid, resulting in a 27.8% yield of HMF in an aqueous medium with poor selectivity. The slight deactivation of the Nb2O5·nH2O@Re-Cellulose catalyst was possibly due to the formation of humins byproducts that adhere to the surface of the catalyst [124,125]. Silica gel, a distinct structural variant of silicon, served as an effective medium for the immobilization of Brønsted and Lewis acid derivatives. This research examined the correlation between acidity and catalytic activity, highlighting its potential for reuse in the dehydration reaction of fructose to produce HMF [126,127]. Flexible carriers have gradually gained widespread attention in the field of HMF chemical catalysis. However, their synthesis process is relatively complex, and their selectivity and stability are also relatively weak. Therefore, there is limited research in the field of HMF synthesis. In the future, further optimization of the performance and structure of flexible materials should be made to make them suitable for more applications. Detailed information of the reaction of immobilized of chemical catalysts for HMF synthesis are shown in Table 3 . 3.2 Immobilized chemical catalysts for HMF oxidation derivatives synthesis The application of chemical catalysts immobilization in the synthesis of HMF oxidation derivatives was mainly focused on DFF, HMFCA and FDCA. These derivatives mainly used HMF as the substrate for catalytic oxidation. Certain immobilized carriers utilized in the synthesis of HMF remain relevant for the synthesis of DFF. ILs was immobilized using expanded corn starch, and imidazolium chloride was subsequently grafted onto the surface of catalyst. Following a reaction period of 5 h in an oxygen-rich environment at a temperature of 50 °C, a yield of 98% for DFF was achieved [128]. Additionally, Zhong et al. [129] had employed a Pal-supported Ru catalyst to facilitate a synergistic reaction in a toluene solution at 110 °C and 10 bar of O2 for 4.5 h, resulting in a 100% conversion of HMF and a DFF selectivity of 98%. The activation of the intermediate by the Ru active site was also observed. The slight activity loss indicated insoluble polymers like humus adsorbing on the surface of catalyst. These by-products were not completely removed after washing, and they covered the metal active sites, thereby leading to slightly diminished catalytic activity. Besides, AES results of the solution after the fifth reaction show the leaching loss of Ru was about 0.055% of the Ru content in the fresh catalyst, which may cause a very slight decrease of catalytic activity (Figs. 8(A)–(D) ). Furthermore, it was determined that TEMPO is a chemical agent capable of catalyzing the oxidation of HMF. ILs was co-immobilized with TEMPO through the use of pyridine or CuCl, resulting in the development of a novel catalytic system. However, the volatility of TEMPO contributed to a gradual decline in DFF yield during the heating process [130,131]. In the investigation of DFF synthesis, ILs and TEMPO are frequently employed to enhance the selectivity of the reaction, however, the economic implications of their industrial application warrant further examination. Moreover, the separation of the reaction mixture from the resultant product remains a significant challenge in large-scale operations. Carbon nanotubes and silicon-based carriers continued to demonstrate efficacy as carriers for DFF synthesis. Ru was effectively immobilized using functionalized carbon nanotube polymer-carbon composites, and the primary reaction parameters had been systematically assessed. Under optimal conditions, a yield of 94% could be achieved, however, this catalyst exhibited significant demands regarding the concentration of O2 [132]. Guo et al. [133] employed a two-component assembly method to immobilize VO2 onto polyaniline-functionalized CNTs, resulting in the formation of VO2-PANI/CNT. This carrier exhibited a preference for the adsorption of HMF, achieving a DFF yield of 96% and enhancing selectivity. The decreased catalytic performance of VO2-PANI/CNT in the recycling can presumably be related to the leaching of approximately 30% of the vanadium from VO2-PANI/CNT after the 5 cycles (Figs. 8 (E) and (F)). SBA-15 continues to be a widely utilized silicon-based carrier medium. Following the functionalization of this carrier, either TEMPO or a metal was immobilized. Acetic acid and [bis(acetoxy) iodo] benzene (BAIB) were introduced as co-oxidants within an oxygen-rich environment. This process facilitates the in situ regeneration of TEMPO, resulting in a yield of 73% for DFF [134]. Furthermore, utilizing Cu and V as catalysts, MCM-41 was employed to support both catalysts, with MCM-NH2-Cu2+ serving as a co-catalyst. The catalytic performance of MCM-NH2-VO2+ in the oxidation of HMF was significantly enhanced, yielding an optimal result of 61.2% [135]. To facilitate the rapid recovery of the catalyst, Fe3O4@SiO2-NH2 was developed to immobilize Cu2+ and VO2+, achieving a yield of 85.5%, and was subsequently employed for recycling via magnetic separation [136]. Additionally, Vicente et al. [137] innovatively utilized 5-chloromethylfurfural (CMF) as the substrate for the reaction, employing thermal and microwave irradiation to enhance the catalytic activity of Cu@SiO2, thereby accelerating the oxidation of the substrate by the oxidant pyridine N-oxide. Although a 54% yield of DFF was achieved, a significant quantity of by-products, including HMF and 5,5’-oxybis(5-methylene-2-furanaldehyde) (OBMF) were also detected. Transition metal elements have good redox properties in transition metal oxides, and there are many oxidation states, which enable them to quickly lose or obtain electrons in the reaction. The appropriate immobilized carriers can effectively increase the dispersion of the catalyst and improve the stability, which make the transition metal oxide type immobilized catalysts widely used in catalytic DFF synthesis. However, these immobilized transition metal oxides may exhibit poor matching and catalytic effects due to the different environments required by the carriers and the catalysts. Therefore, special attention should be paid to this problem when using this kind of immobilized catalyst, so that the immobilized catalyst can exert the best effect. The alkaline environment played a crucial role in the synthesis of FDCA. The MgSi-ZSM-12 heteroatom zeolite was synthesized directly through a hydrothermal method. The basicity of the catalyst was significantly improved through the in-situ incorporation of Mg, resulting in the immobilization of nanoparticles within this carrier. This modification led to an impressive yield of 87% for FDCA in a sustainable conventional environment. (Figs. 9(A)–(C) ) [138]. The natural clay mineral cordierite serves as an economical and straightforward alkaline support carrier. When utilized for the immobilization of bimetallic Pt-Pd in an aqueous solution without the addition of alkali for a duration of 12 h, a yield of 99% for FDCA was achieved [139]. In contrast, a novel catalyst comprising Au nanoparticles immobilized on activated carbon did not create an alkaline environment, however, FDCA could still be synthesized under alkaline conditions. It has been observed that smaller Au nanoparticles exhibited greater selectivity for FDCA, indicating that the influence of particle size on catalytic performance warrants careful consideration during catalyst formation. After 5 cycles, the FDCA yield decreases from 70% to 58% may be mainly due to the increase of gold particle size [140]. The in-situ synthesis of new immobilized catalysts represents a sophisticated approach, wherein Pd nanoparticles are immobilized on magnetic carbon spheres with a core-shell structure through in-situ adsorption and reduction, with a 91.8% yield of FDCA [141]. Additionally, Zou et al. [142,143] have employed metal porphyrins to mimic the active sites of horseradish peroxidase and P450 monooxygenase, subsequently immobilizing them on SiO2 to create a series of metal catalysts. Following a 12 h reaction in an aqueous solution, a maximum yield of 94.94% was recorded. Furthermore, Liu et al. [144] had utilized Cu2+ as a co-catalyst to assist VO2+ in the context of SBA-15 immobilization, resulting in yields of 62.7% for DFF and 28.9% for FDCA. Despite the successful production of the target compounds, the separation of the two remains a challenging task. Additionally, a nanofiber membrane was developed, featuring a Pd/Au catalyst immobilized on various polymers via electrospinning. This catalyst facilitated the oxidation of HMF in an aqueous phase, resulting in an enhanced FDCA yield. After 5 cycles, the yield of FDCA decreased from 99% to 86%. The reason of the decrease of FDCA yield was due to the loss of PVA stabilizer in the recycle process, which led to the aggravation of nanoparticle sintering [145]. Alina et al. [146] employed magnetic nanoparticles composed of Mn, Co, and Fe oxides as the core material, with Nb-MCM-41 serving as the shell. This multifunctional magnetic nano immobilized catalyst was utilized to activate t-BuOOH in the catalytic conversion of HMF, resulting in a selectivity of 96.5% for FDCA. Furthermore, a series of CeO2 modified CC@NiFe-LDH were synthesized by varying the electrodeposition time, yielding a high FDCA output of 93.31% and a Faraday efficiency of 99.47% through electrochemical methods [147]. The above series of immobilized metal catalysts are used to synthesize FDCA with good yield and selectivity. Since the formation process of FDCA requires a certain alkaline environment, these metal catalysts can form a certain alkaline environment in the solution, which provide a certain environmental guarantee for the directional selection of FDCA. At the same time, the deprotonation effect of these basic metals can enhance the nucleophilicity of the reaction substrate, which are conducive to further improve the catalytic performance. Moreover, these immobilized carriers also seem to have good adaptability to the alkaline environment, further protecting the catalyst and improving the stability. These key combinations of conditions make the current research progress of FDCA show a good trend. In the future, the interaction mechanism between immobilized metal catalysts and microenvironment can be further studied to fundamentally grasp the principle of FDCA efficient catalysis. Research on the synthesis of HMFCA remained limited, indicating significant potential for further investigation in this area. The co-immobilization of phosphotungstic heteropoly acid and Ru nanoparticles was employed to facilitate the synthesis of HMFCA from HMF. However, the reaction conditions were quite severe, necessitating a high temperature of 130 °C and an oxygen flow rate of 20 mL/min. After a duration of 12 h, a yield of 72.9% was achieved. Unfortunately, the catalyst exhibited limited stability throughout the reaction, with a noticeable decline in activity observed during the cyclic experiments. The decrease of the Ru/CsPW catalyst was not caused by the leach of the active sites into the reaction solution. The possible reasons should be caused by the absorption of byproducts such as humins on the surface of the catalyst or the change of physical properties of the metallic ruthenium nanoparticles [148]. Molybdenum dioxide was immobilized on montmorillonite clay, and HMF was oxidized in a toluene solution under aerobic conditions. After a reaction period of 3 h, a yield of 86.9% for HMFCA was achieved (Fig. 9(D)) [149]. Additionally, both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts were developed by immobilizing Nb2O5 on a flexible support resin and a water-soluble polymer, poly sodium methacrylate, respectively, and H2O2 was used as oxidant. Interestingly, both types of catalysts demonstrated remarkable activity, resulting in a complete conversion of HMF and a selectivity of 100% for HMFCA (Fig. 9(E)) [150]. The unique characteristics of HMFCA functional groups present challenges in the catalytic synthesis of HMFCA from HMF, as it is essential to preserve the hydroxyl group while oxidizing the aldehyde group to form a carboxyl group. At the same time, the use of non-O2 oxidant much decreases the practical usefulness of the oxidation system. Despite these difficulties, recent research has yielded promising results, suggesting that further advancements in the synthesis of HMFCA are anticipated in the future. Detailed information of the reaction of immobilized of chemical catalysts for HMF oxidation derivatives synthesis are shown in Table 4 . 4 Conclusion and perspectives This review summarizes an overview of recent advancements in research and the prospective applications of immobilized catalysts in the synthesis of high-value HMF and its oxidation derivatives. The design and optimization of high-performance immobilized catalysts, as well as the investigation of catalytic mechanisms, with the objective of enhancing the catalytic efficiency, selectivity, and recyclability of HMF and its oxidation derivatives under milder conditions have been discussed. The integration of immobilized catalysts into the production processes of biomass resources represents a significant strategy for progress in this area. Ongoing research efforts aim to refine immobilized catalyst technologies to facilitate the development of high-performance, stable, and controllable immobilization methods that are suitable for large-scale production and industrial applications of HMF and its oxidation derivatives. Recent studies suggest that the development of immobilized catalysts predominantly employs conventional trial-and-error approaches, with their utilization in the production of HMF and its oxidized derivatives largely confined to small-scale experimental settings. While innovative catalyst synthesis methodologies have been introduced, challenges such as suboptimal conversion efficiency and inadequate selectivity persist. To fulfill the requirements of practical industrial applications, further advancements in the design of high-performance immobilized catalysts are essential. The application of artificial intelligence technology may facilitate the design of catalysts across a wider array of synthesis conditions and enable the rapid screening of immobilized catalysts capable of functioning efficiently and selectively under mild conditions, thereby enhancing the intentional and effective utilization of biomass resources. From a theoretical perspective, there remains a significant gap in the understanding of the active sites of various immobilized catalysts and the interaction mechanisms between the support materials and catalytic components. Consequently, investigating the molecular mechanisms and structure-activity relationships of immobilized catalysts is vital for a more comprehensive understanding of their catalytic behaviors and mechanisms. This investigation can be conducted through computational chemistry and advanced in situ characterization techniques to address this critical scientific challenge. Furthermore, traditional catalytic processes frequently result in the formation of by-products, which can escalate separation costs and diminish atom economy. New approaches that enable the integration of by-products into the primary reaction or the generation of another high-value chemical that is more readily separable from the desired product, thereby enhancing substrate utilization efficiency are promising in future research. In the existing production methodology, the oxidation derivatives of HMF are synthesized exclusively through the oxidation of HMF itself. However, it is feasible to directly produce high-value products from catalytic feedstocks, such as glucose and cellulose, by employing immobilized catalysts and other environmentally sustainable catalytic technologies. Immobilized catalysts represent an innovative advancement in green and sustainable technology. The proposed research trajectory holds considerable importance for minimizing production expenses while aligning with the tenets of green chemistry. In the future, the engineering implementation of this methodology in the context of HMF and its oxidized derivatives is expected to offer significant theoretical insights and practical engineering experiences that could facilitate its application in other areas of biomass resource utilization. Dr. Jun Ge is a professor at Department of Chemical Engineering Tsinghua University. He received his B.Sc. and Ph.D. from the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University in 2004 and 2009. From 2009 to 2012, He did his postdoc in the Department of Chemistry, Stanford University. Prof. Ge specializes in enzymatic catalysis, synthetic biology, nanobiotechnology and biomedicine. He has been carrying out scientific research projects from government and industry, including the Distinguished Young Scholars Fund from NSFC, the Excellent Young Scientists Fund from NSFC, the Program of National Key Research and Development Plan of China, and the Distinguished Young Scholars of Beijing National Science Foundation. Prof. Ge has published over 100 papers in journals such as Nature Nanotechnology, Nature Catalysis, Nature Communications, Science Advances, JACS etc. He was selected as the member of MIT Technology Review's World 35 Innovators Under 35 and was awarded as the young scholar of Yangzi River Scholarship and the Future Chemical Engineering Scholar of the Global Academy of Chinese Chemical Engineers.

coredata.dc:description: 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and its oxidation derivatives have emerged as a bridge between biomass resources and the future energy industry. These renewable biomass resources can be transformed into a variety of value-added chemicals, thereby addressing the challenges posed by diminishing fossil fuel reserves and environmental concerns. The immobilization of catalysts represents an innovative method for the sustainable and efficient synthesis of HMF and its oxidation derivatives. This method not only enhances the yield and selectivity of the products but also allows for the optimization of the catalytic performance of immobilized catalysts through the strategic design of their supports. In this review, we provide an overview of the recent advancements in the technology of immobilized catalyst and its application in the synthesis of HMF and its oxidation derivatives, with a particular focus on the preparation and catalytic characteristics of these immobilized catalysts. Furthermore, we discuss potential future directions for the development of immobilized catalysts, including the preparation of high-performance immobilized catalysts, the exploration of their growth and catalytic mechanisms, and the economic implications of raw material utilization. This area of research presents both significant promise and considerable challenges.
